reviewerDisplayName: Look at it, it's got anxiety
reviewText:
I had an entire population of over 300 die because there were too many farms spread out over too large an area. Farmers took too long to reach the farms from their houses to do work, so everyone died of starvation.

At the end there was just a woman and two children who lived with her. Every day she would go to pick up eggs from the overpopulated, decaying chicken coup to feed the only two reasons she had to live.

It was not enough, after a couple of years the two children died of starvation. You could see the loss in her, her happiness rating down to 1/2 a star out of 5...

She made her way to the woodcutter's to fetch some firewood. Once she had picked some up and walked a short distance, the firewood was put back down again.

She had snapped. The two reasons she had to live were gone. All of her friends were dead. All of her family lost. She was all alone in a ghost town, there was no escape. There was no point.

She picked up the firewood.
She put it back down.
She picked up the firewood.
She put it back down.
She picked up the firewood.
She put it back down.

You could see the insanity she had taken over. She just wanted it to end.

Over and over she just picked up the firewood and put it back down again, as she tried to burn as much energy as possible on this pointless act so that her death might just come a little sooner...

It took a while, it took a long long while, but finally the bells of death rang.

The woman had died of starvation.

Banished is a wonderful city/town sim. I suggest you try it out.

reviewText:
Summary: Lots of fun for a city-builder, definitely worth 20 USD.  Took me 50 hours of playtime to get all achievements.

Long Version: You remember the rabbit in Monty Python's Holy Grail?  It's a lot like that.  You start off with this cute little bunny of a village, then all at once, it lunges for your throat and leaves you bloody and beaten.

Banished is full of ripple effects:  Everything's running smoothly and you feel confident in building another house?  20 years later, because of that extra house, everyone is dying of starvation, freezing to death or dying of diptheria.

My laborious little laborers have been trampled, stabbed, plagued, frozen, crushed, drowned, burnt, swept away, and one lucky teacher went batshit crazy.  And yet, humanity persevered and thrived.

It's a game filled with subtleties and harsh lessons, but definitely worth playing!

reviewText: This game is great.  It is solid gameplay at a fair price.  It is more challenging than your standard sim because everything has direct consequences, moreso than in other sims.  For instance, if let yourself run low on tools, you will quickly find that people don't work as effectively.  People that don't work effectively are mining for the materials that the blacksmith makes to make the tools.  So you run out of iron, coal, and logs to make tools.  Farmers, hunters, and other food bearing people need these tools.  So then you starve and your village becomes a ghost town, all because you let yourself run low on tools.\n\nThe game mechanics remind me of back when Stronghold was a good game, a couple releases back.  There were things in Stronghold that I wish were in this game, such as taking wheat to a mill to make flour that you take to a bakery to bake bread.  More of a tech tree"
date: if you will.  But the few elements that this game does have (metal

reviewText:
Banished is a very well thought game about town management and survival. You take control of a small community of outcasts and attempt to keep them alive as long as you can in a verdent but harsh environment. You will have engineer your town to provide the necessities of life not only for your workers, but also for those too young to provide for themselves. Those needs include shelter, fuel, food, clothing, tools (non-fatal) education (non-fatal), medical services, wells for fighting fires as well as sourses of wood, stone, iron and other resourses for the production of said items and for the growth of your town.

It is the first game I have seen that has penelties for not expanding your town regulaurly. As your population ages, your older workers will die off and, if no new childeren have been born for some time, you may run low on citizens old enough to work.
(Adults will move into new houses and begin raising children if new houses are avaliable, but older adults can't raise children)

in addition to the need for basic nesessities and growth, your workers must walk to their place of work, meaning that you must make sure enough housing is nearby for them to live in (but they will exchange jobs automaticaly to minimize the legnth of their walking paths)

There is also the ability to trade with other towns for needed resourses and unlock new types of food by trading.

Medieval setting.

bugs of note:

-laborers (the default task) may die to starvation if a task is set too far from their home no matter how much food is available.

-roads cannot always be removed by the remove road tool once placed.

-game crash if you set orders for a merchent after they have already left your dock.

A very intuitive, interesting, and relaxing game that challenges you to make the best use of the resourses avaliable to you and create a major metropolis from sticks and stones. Very impressed with the game's design and how seemless the game experience is from start to finish.

reviewText: I'm going to say yes, for recommending this game so far, but it has a large caveat - it really has no longevity imo. There's one developer working on the entire game, and yes it's a pretty nice game so far. It's somewhat different from a lot of sim/city building games, in that it really does focus on survival - no food = your entire population dying out very quickly. But when there is really no major depth to the game (by the time you end up with a few hundred people in a stable pop you've basically beaten all the game has to offer.. there's just nothing more to offer. You can set your own goals in terms of what pop you reach or having every kind of seed and animal etc, but for me, just not a great deal to offer at the moment. Hopefully the game is either not difficult to mod, or the developer has a LOT easier time to develop additional content for the game now because if it's going to take him 6 months to push out a new profession or similar, then I can't see this going anywhere unfortunately.\n\n6, maybe 7/10.

reviewText: Let's get some technical questions out of the way. The User Interface is fluid. The game is responsive. The attention to detail is astounding. When you build farms, you don't just have a farm, you are allowed to choose between a dozen food types. Your main resources are wood, stone, iron, coal. Which you harvest in familiar ways. The options are what stand out to me in this game. Other simulations might have you build farms for every 10 people or some other fixed value. In Bansihed you have choices. Lots of choices. Lots and Lots of choices. You might start the game only knowing how to farm squash. But everntually you will be able to have over a dozen fruits, vegetables, and meats to choose from. You have farms, in the typical fashion, but you have orchards now. This allows your brewer to use any fruits, or wheat to make ales. You have fruit and nut trees. You have over a dozen food choices to from. Corn, pumpkin, squash, wheat, beans, and more. Easily worth the $20 i dropped on it. I missed it on sale for 15 by a few hours. Already have 20 hours in the game. So at $1 an hour, well worth the investment, and I'm just getting started.

reviewText: The premier medieval city administration simulator. I think that says it all. This is not really a standard city builder. You basically spend most of your time manageing your citizens and making sure that they survive. There is no porgression or tech, you just start out with 20 some odd buildings and a virgin land to settle in. The fun of the game is really in figuring out how produce enough food/tools/clothes/medicine/etc to prevent everyone from dying. After that initial phase it is then about seeing how large you can get your city. There aren't any massive building projects and the game really lacks on aesthetics. You spend most of your time carefully placing buildinds, watching your supplies, and managing how many people are in each profession. If that sounds interesting then it's deffinately worth the buy.

You'll have to get used to it at first, as you'll probably have a famine like I did.

reviewText: First off, the AI is absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Secondly, their retardation manages to keep them alive for surprisingly long.\nCitizens are selfish, they hoard ALL the food that they can while others starve to death.\nThat aside, the game is surprisingly fun albeit frustrating from time to time. The game can also be very difficult (it is highly likely that your first town will not succeed or be very unstable and wobbly before failing altogether). The game is time consuming and very stretched out, but like I said it does offer a challenge and I can reccomend this game despite its minor faults.

reviewText:
Town one: The villagers spent too much time clear cutting the forrests they had no food for the winter and all starved to death

Town two: The villagers were able to survive the first winter and managed to survive a raging fire. However the second  winter was cold and dark and everyone froze solid.

Town three: The village flurished and grew for many years. Unfortunately no one had a proper sex education and did not have families. instead they just grew old and frail until one day a group of immigrants came and took over the land. Many years later a tornado left a young child and a few elders stranded on an island with just enough resources to stay warm and fed for a decent amount of years. The elders died of old age quickly which left just the young boy to witness the rest of his village die from a ruthless epidemic. He could do nothing but watch all his friends and family die from his island just off the coast. The child starved after 7 years alone on that island.

Toronde: Toronde is currently a thriving village of 100 surviving off of its main export fire wood". Other than a few small fires no real problems have occured we can only hope the vilage continues to remain stable. We can only pray. at the chaple the people have built for the one god...Shrek. pray for Shrek to protect them from the disasters that may be on there way. Shrek is love.... Shrek is life

10/10 great game"

To start off with.

This is not an easy game. It won't hold your hand, it won't tell you what to do. Your first few tries will end with everyone either starving to death or freezing to death. Besides all that, I love this game.

reviewText: I have had so much fun with this game and have told so many friends to stat playing it. Every little detail about the game is interlinked; for example - you can welcome Nomads to boost your towns population and workforce, however; if you do not have enough food stocked up the instant increase in population will deplete your food limit and people will start to die of starvation. I would definitely reccoment this game to anyone who enjoys world-building games but I also find it is an accessible game to those who aren't so familiar with similar games. Definitely reccoment. Absolutely love it so far.

reviewText:
For a one man created City Builder, it hits it pretty well on the nose. While not the biggest game, Banished has a nice amount to offer.
You can set the difficulty using the starting equipment the climate and the type of map. Should you start with seeds and a heard of animals to help feed your banished brotherin? or are you going to face the unknown with nothing but a few hunters and gatherers?

If you enjoy games like the settlers, anno series, even stronghold (for the economy side, then this game wont fail to amuse you!

reviewText:
I thought it was just a simple sim management game with adorable tiny structures and people. I was really wrong.

My first playthrough was full of rage quits and depression from disasters and unfortunate events that kills your village growth.

But then I realised that it is how to recover from each disaster is what make the game special. If the village is totally hopeless, I'll start a new one and learn from previous mistakes. Then I started to try to achieve the achievements one at a time and it was a very rewarding gaming experience.

I totally recommend this game if you have the patience.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a peaceful, relaxing game.  No combat, no soldiers, no defenses, no conquering what-so-ever.  The game primarily focuses on resource management, especially food management.  You grow your city at your own pace, fast or slow, doesn't matter.  The traders come very rarely at first which is a bit of a milestone.  From them you can purchase seeds, livestock, food, etc. in exchange for your own goods.  Not all traders have the same thing.  One might have peach seeds while the next 5 might have coats and leather.  I've played games that take years before I get livestock.\n\nThe visuals, ambient music and sound effects, are all pretty good.

reviewText:
If you like city building games i can highly recommend Banished. Its lots of fun and a real challenge to keep your villagers happy en well fed over a period of time.

You start out with a few family’s gathering resources and building your homes, but be prepared winter is coming and she isn’t going to be mild, so make sure you have warm clothes and enough food in your barn.

Also as a player make sure you are warm and well fed because Banished is going to claim allot of your spare time making the best community for your people and I am sure you will enjoy every minute of it.

This is one of the best city builders I played in a long time!

reviewText:
A nice, slow-pace medieval village builder that focuses on survival instead of technological progress.  Despite the limited nature of this type of game... the strategy is brutal and unforgiving.

There is a lot of replayability as long as you don't rage easily when 8+ hours of gameplay get ruined by poor early planning.

If you like city builders, and are open for some lovely gameplay and new strategies... give it a shot.

reviewText:
It is a pretty nice game. It seems to be difficult at begin but after few hours you get the tricks and can have a got start then, even on hard conditions. The interface is easy to operate so you don't have to search for anything too long. At some point you will make your actions automaticly.

In some aspects, this game is unbalanced (e.g. amount houses needed for population to grow with population that exceeds 300 citizens or getting enough firewood for that population). I am not going to say that those are bad, becuase I couldn't handle it. I suppose in reality it could be the same. You have to think in order to let the town grow smoothly and if you are too lazy to think, just try again :P

The disasters which can destroy your town are awesome. I had a town with about 350-400 citizens and tornado had struck it. As you can predict almost everything have been destroyed. I have lost about 80% of population citizens left so I had to build everything again. I haven't done that but I loaded the previous saved game in order to avoid waisting additional time.

reviewText:
This review is based on the current vanilla version of the game, which is to be regarded as completely finished (There will not be any further updates or patches).

THE GOOD
+ It's Different: Banished is a city-, or rather, village builder. The main goal, however, is not to build a prosperous metropolis, but to keep your citizens alive in a hostile environment. The key to this is wise resource management and proper planning. Banished has been called The Dark Souls of City Builders" and I can agree with this. It may seem very hard - even unfair - at first
date: but once you understand the mechanics
recommended: it becomes very doable as long as you keep paying attention.\n\n+ Actual Simulation: Every single citizen is born to a family
hoursPlayed: given a (weird) name and after growing up and finishing school
voteText: will get a job

votesTotal: buildings don't just plop up where you order them built
votesFunny: the necessary materials have to be carried to the location
commentsCount: after which you can watch the structure being erected in two or three visible stages. Your workers have to get there first though
column16: which means the farther away from established infrastructure you chose to build
column17: the longer it will take (and the less efficient production buildings will be).\n\n+ The Achievements: There are no "Do something incredibly moronic and counter-intuitive that will totally frack up your savegame
column18: or just be a boring grind that will taint your memory of the game if you care enough about achievements to actually do it" type achievements. Almost all of them are just about doing well at the game. The others
column19: like "Mountain Men"
column20:
can be viewed as scenarios (which are otherwise missing from the game).

+ The Bugs: I haven't encountered any.



THE "MEH"
~ Graphics: The graphics are OK
column21: i.e. "not ugly". Fully zoomed out
column22: they're even kind of charming
column23: as long as you ignore stuff like the river-crossing Jesus Deer.\n\n~ Sound: The loop of a very limited number of background music tracks quickly becomes boring
column24: but at least the music isn't annoying (to me). The same cannot be said for some of the ambience sounds like the mooing of cows or the gusts of wind
column25: which are constant if you play on x10 speed. MOO MOO MOO WOOOSH MOO MOO MOO WOOOSH MOO MOO MOO WOOOSH AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARGH. You'll probably play with (ambience-) sound off after a while. (Why isn't this under "bad"? Because it's almost enjoyable on x1 speed.)\n\n~ Resource Management Tools: While overall very well done
column26: they're lacking in some parts. E.g.:\n\n- You can place production limits on all manufactured goods
column27: including clothing
column28: but not on leather and wool
column29: which are needed for clothing. If you produce slightly more raw materials than your tailor uses (and if you don't keep an eye on this)
column30: your storage barns will eventually overflow with them
column31: meaning there's no space for produced goods anymore. This is exaggerated when the clothing limit has been reached and the tailors stop production.\n\n- You cannot prohibit citizens from using certain goods. They will eat the wheat intended for your brewers to make ale and they will use coal instead of firewood to heat their homes if coal is stored closer to the market than firewood at that moment. (You need coal for steel tools). You also cannot limit selected stockpiles to only store certain goods
column32: or a maximum amount of a specific good.\n\nThese are minor issues and there are ways to get around them
column33: but it certainly isn't optimal.\n\n~ Variety: There's not a lot of it
column34: except in food. There are very few building types and even fewer upgrades (one for houses). But hey
column35:
it works and there is enough to manage.



THE BAD
- Performance: This simulation-heavy game is not optimized to run on multi-core processors and will only use one core. This results in simulation speed and FPS drops after a certain amount of citizens in your town. The point of the game slowing to a constant crawl was reached at a population of around 1000 in my case (i7 5930K). This is quite late in the game though. Point of reference: The highest population achievement is 900.



CONCLUSION
I obviously enjoyed playing Banished and I sincerely recommend it to everyone who is interested enough to read through this review. It's a good game. Not great

reviewText: The game is very much a balancing act where your most important resource is your citizens. The citizens have their own names, houses, families, and places of work. They have children who grow up, go to school, then join the workforce. They grow old and die unless something else catches them first. There are many ways to lose citizens and that's where you come in. They need food, they need shelter, they need clothing and firewood for warmth; they need medicines and balanced diets for health. All of these needs are met by industries set up by you, the player, and you must manage your workforce effectively. You may build a dock and conduct trade for the things you need. There is no currency, you trade items you need for items you have in surplus of equal value. Natural disasters are in the game if you so choose. Tornadoes, fire, disease, crop infestations, early frost, among others.\n\nIf you like the idea of micromanaging on a small scale that eventually becomes a large fine tuned machine, or a chaotic train wreck of despair then this game is certainly something to pick up. There's plenty to discover and tweak just right to keep you trying new things.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Extremely well done peaceful survival/city-builder simulator.

Few words of warning: It is paradoxically better to start with harder starting conditions, otherwise you can easily overspend/overexpand your initial stock and then end up with broken economy.

Great, clear and aesthetically pleasing graphics, nicely connected and thought-out industries, good artiffical intelligence, working trade system, and MOD support!

reviewText: When I first played Banished, I greatly underestimated the numbers involved. Its not like a traditional simbuilder where you just keep an eye on income, but you have to keep an eye on literally everything your villagers do. It has a decent learning curve though and it is a very good example of trial by error". It takes a few attempts to get a good village going
date: but you shouldn't let that stop you from trying again and again. It's very rewarding to notice you keep doing better and better at the game.\n\nOne final important piece to notice though is that this game will start to lag the larger your town becomes. Some people with bad computers will notice a slowdown after 500 inhabitants
recommended: I noticed a huge lag/slowdown at 1000 inhabitants. I recommend just playing on a medium map.\n\nDont expect a thrilling story or objectives and goals. This game only has two goals: expand and survive. It's a great game "to pass time"."

reviewText:
My thoughts on Banished...

This game has been produced by a single person, so first off congratulations on such a tough task!

Banished is a city/town building game which combines survival elements found in many recent games. It has a vast array of building types, jobs for citizens and can be extremely engrossing.

Graphically this game looks wonderful, small details here and there offer the world a lot more depth. Colours looks fantastic as seasons come and go, caking the landscape in snow or lush green hills.

The tutorial lays everything out for a newcomer to the series, though making sure you complete every single one provided is key to success.

Lastly this game includes mod support and some mods that the community has cooked up are really interesting but NOT required to enjoy this game since the vanilla version is extremely well done.

Props to the developer and i look forward to future DLCs for games you release.

10/10

reviewText:
The thing that Banished can hold over any game that at least I've ever played is the simple playstyle for players of the game. You look at people's hours and it's probably confusing seeing someone with 5 hours say they've made 10 cities and others have over a 100 hours and still be on their first city. There's a button that allows gameplay be at standard speed (I'd say roughly 20-30 minutes per year) and options from 2x, 5x and 10x (10x makes it a mere couple minutes.)

Now what's unique about this is it allows those who enjoy all management style games to play at their own speed depending how much they like to control their 'resources'. If you are a relaxed gamer when it comes to the genre, such as myself, then you can easily stroll through the game controlling life in your city casually. It's slow enough too to where you can multi-task while playing, like I enjoy watching professional CS:GO on Twitch, so I'll watch that and have this game open and check on it once or twice a minute. If you're someone who wants stuff done right now, then the 10x mode is perfect for you. It's not like a speed demon mode or time trial, but it's definitely rapid gameplay for a management game.

Now this game is on the harder side of management games, now I still recommend all ages for this game but to truly do well at this game you probably need some experience with other games of the genre. What's hard is once something goes wrong (resource depletes, natural disaster, etc.) then it's pretty much all over for your city. It's hard because it can be simply one resource that causes the downfall of the city, and it's not a common one like food or clothing that can ruin your economy or happiness of your city.

The main objective that I usually shoot for in this game is to simply grow my city and the number of citizens,  and that seems to be the only goal in this game. With that, you can set up your own personal goals and if you're an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥ then this game has some pretty difficult ones for you to get, especially if you're a relaxed gamer.

A good pickup for the management gurus and a good one for the chill gamers.

Topic: Strategy Simulation Management

*Curator's pick for MANAGEMENT*

reviewText:
I was honestly surprised by this game. It was a lot harder than I thought it would be, as unlike other medieval city builders which usually involve combat and enemies. In this game the only enemy is nature. Whether it be a bad harvest causing half of your population to starve to death, or an unexpected snow causing your civilians to freeze because you were unprepared and didn't have enough firewood. An outbreak of syphilis because you opened your city to nomads or you forgot to make room for extra population so your people stopped reproducing and then all died at once from old age, leaving useless incapable children which do nothing except drain your resources. Or of course a aggressive tornado rips through your city leaving nothing but rubble and ♥♥♥♥ing children..

It's quite a challenge and your city will probably die for your first few attempts but it's a lot of fun and I'd recommend it.
The game was made by one guy and that's impressive. 9/10

reviewText: This is what I told my friend to try and get him to play banished:\n\nHad a really good self-sustaining economy going, like 10 hours of gametime on this one map, growing my whole village, high happiness, high health, plenty of goods for trading, a varied diet for my citizens, 100% education, 100% of my citizens were clothed and fed everything was going great, had loads of food stockpiled, but then my population started growing at a ridiculous rate, i tried to keep up by building new housing estates and also tried to increase my food production, then 1 Spring i forgot to plant crops for harvesting in the autumn, big mistake. Bam next thing you know within 1 year of game time I had lost 50% of my population, there was no stopping it as well, because my village was so geographically large, the food production wasn't centralised enough, so no matter how many people i put into food production, people were dying before they actually got to the storage areas to get the food. Eventually after 2 years of game time trying to save it, I knew it was over. Eventually I just sat there watching the simulation run at 10x speed. By the end I had about 5% of my 600 strong population left, and still they continued dying. 12 hours of game time down the tubes cos of a Malthusian catastrophe. That is Banished. So. Good.

reviewText:
For short version, Banished - without a proper story or purpose - is a magnificent game for people who likes to create what they want to create. City building, micro management, lovely sounds, realistic graphics, medieval theme, simulation. If you like at least 3 of these things you need to take a look at this game.

There are plenty of achievements and they are HARD ( or just long, depends on your gameplay skill). You can create your own story behind that town. You can watch your exiled villagers. If you are powerful enough, you can even play long enough to see that they are improved theirselves and they don't need their civilization which banished them at first.

In conclusion : If you have enough time to spend on games like this, DO NOT even think a second time. This game will be known as one of the legendary games and after 10 years or something when people talk about it you can say, '' well i was playing it before it was cool.''

Because the developer opened the game to other developers, it gets updates and there are a lot of workshop items for it. Banished has a future.

reviewText:
I have absolutely NO REGRETS purchasing this. An odd - yet beautiful - blend of complexity and simplicity.
Unlike most city-building rts games, Banished focuses on survival; there's no money involved. At all. You start from scratch, work your way up by living off the land, and eventually you'll be able to barter your resources for other resources.
This game requires proper strategy and management. And since there's no single permanent map, scarcity and abundance of resources may vary with each map seed.
Here's a very basic 'what to do' list for this game:
> name your town
> live off the land
> make sure your citizens do not freeze to death or die from starvation
> grow!

9/10 - 9 because the way the game changes from one season to the other seems a bit too quick for me. Though overall it's an impressive game.

reviewText:
This game IS addictive, challenging, relaxing, and really a pleasure to play.

The background music is almost hypnotic - I think there must be something subliminal buried in it xD.  Hours after I've turned off the computer, I find that repeating tune stuck in my head.  God help me, I love it.

As of this writing, over 91% of the reviews are Positive, and there is good reason for that.  The game is a winner.  There are an almost infinite number of scenarios to choose from, with some childishly easy to succeed at (a good place for beginners to start), and the difficulties go all the way up to essentially unsurvivable.

The incredible number of MODs available to choose from in the Workshop also adds so much richness and variety to the game.  There is a HUGE Banished community growing and supporting the game and its MODS.  The one scenario that seems to disturb me most is the two settlers, Adam & Eve scenario - LOL, where brothers wind up marrying sisters, and then 1st cousins, etc.  Now, that's a genuine Uncle Daddy & Aunt Mama family tree.  Anybody on earth should find that hilariously funny, with no disrespect meant to Arkansans.... Bless their hearts.

I've seen a few critical reviews that reference Sim City, and such, and if that's all they see here with Banished, they came in the door with the wrong expectations.  I own multiple generations of the Sim City series dating back to Win95, as well as, Cities XL, Cities in Motion, and so on.  Banished has little in common with those, IMHO.

The Banished player gets the chance to more closely manage resources and activities, and essentially 'craft' to build more complex structures, more sophisticated clothing, etc. (Hint - warmer settlers work more efficiently in harsh winters).  This is not a high pressure, can't go AFK for a coffee or bathroom break, kind of game.  So, settle in, relax, and enjoy.  For frenzied, Constant ACTION, Run 'n Gun players, there's always a Call of Duty server somewhere, right?!

In short, the Banished player chooses the region and number of initial settlers, as well as starting resources in the game menu.  The race is on to get sufficient shelter, food, and fuel (firewood/coal) before winter sets in.  When it gets cold, you won't see much production from the settlers.  The strategy you start with is up to you.  As for me, early in the game I prefer to focus on Gatherers and an Herbalist (the Healer) before that first winter.  I've had great starts where there were tons of firewood, food, etc., only to see everyone die off to sickness, because I forgot the Herbalist.  Another point I keep in mind is to stockpile absolutely every scrap of firewood, food, and medicine that you can lay hands on to the point of ridiculous excess, so that you can spare settlers to be teachers, preachers, and healers.  Sure, it sounds corny, but Education is important, since educated workers here simply produce more.  Be leery of nomads.  When they show up, they usually lack education, have scores of unproductive, hungry children, and invariably bring disease, so you better have a hospital.  The game never makes it clear what the disease is, but I suspect some nasty STD - LOL.  Again, no offense intended, Arkansans.

When I first started the game, I had settlers dropping like flies, and sadly, my major concern seemed to be having a large enough cemetery.  But now, regardless of difficulty, I manage to keep things balanced enough that the only deaths seem to be from old age - as it should be.  I also highly recommend one of the Mods that change the passage of time to one actual year of gameplay for each year of the settler's life.  The default seems to be several years of life for each four-season Banished year.  When everything is stable for a moment, and little direct input is required, it has a great Fast-Forward x10 that moves things along until a point where more input is required.

A satisfying moment for me is when I'm 8 or 9 game years into a scenario, and I have some of the original potatoes from the wagon in the barn.  That's when you know the food production is more than under control.  Anybody hungry for a 9 year old spud?  I'll pass!

I bought Banished during an earlier Sale, so keep your eyes open for sales.  Frankly, for me it would be worth the money at full retail, so jump at the chance to buy it either way.  More than 91% of the buyers think you'll be glad you did.  I hope this was helpful.  Cheers

reviewText:
What is there to say about Banished that has probably not been said already?

First, and foremost, Banished is a City Builder based upon the premise that you are in charge of the survival of the people. You tell them where to harvest resources and place buildings. What buildings to build and what jobs they must fulfill. This is not a necessarily easy game as it relies upon someone being able to predict the effects that the seasons will have upon your food as well as how many workers will you lose much less gain.

Banished is, for the most part, one of the most realistic city builders that I have seen but I am also the worst to ask about city builders. I've only ever played SimCity, the old ones, and never really took the time to play the newer SimCities [I have a strong dislike for EA]. It touches a part of me that favors the more Medieval period of our history and plays true, for the most part, to how people would live during that time period. This, of course, means you have to handle diseases that would come from the risk of trading with other civilizations or groups. Realism is also pressed farther by the chance that you might hunt deer to extinction or fish the rivers clean. Crops require rotation to keep the soil going and the list goes on.....

The good parts of this game are also, perhaps, the parts I dislike the most however. When my village [As just happened while typing this review] decides to begin starving to death because I never took them to school there is no stopping the constant downward trend. I can place almost every villager I have upon food gathering but it doesn't make a lick of a difference until my once 80 people population turns into 26.  Those 26 also never seem to recover but I'm going to let them continue as my village also just caught fire because of someone apparently attempting to roast a roach [That is my guess, not part of the game].

Should you buy this game? Yes. If only to support the one man team that put work into deveolping a realistic city builder that will create just as much joy, and pain, as it does for me.

reviewText:
For the love of all that is good, gather lots of food and educate the future villagers because idiots in a mine is not what you want. Ever.

Ever.

AND REMEMBER TO BUILD ENOUGH HOUSES SO THEY CAN REPRODUCE AT A REASONABLE RATE! And I do mean REASONABLE!

Perhaps my favorite city builder game there is. Banished is unforgiving and just plain hates you for trying to survive. You don't have to pay to build things, but you need the right supplies, which you'll get from clearing the area. You're going to lose a lot of your villagers at first, so try not to take it too personally.

But what's the satisfaction of playing Banished? There's no campaigns. Nothing except achievements. What do you do?

You play God. You play God and enjoy yourself because it's a nice way to keep yourself distracted. If you're not looking for that sort of simulation experience, this isn't your game.

The community has made some absolutely gorgeous mods that help fix some of the bugs and will also enhance your gameplay. Some improve heavily on the slightly dreary buildings. Some even add an extra animal type for you to butcher! So there's less starvation now!

Or you can play on super hard mode because you're A GOD AND YOU DO NOT TAKE THIS CRAP FROM NOBODY.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely brutal.  That is a good thing.  Normally after playing a typical sandbox city building game for an hour or so, you have the whole system figured out and can game the hell out of it so you can just let it autorun for an hour without any attention.  Banished is a harsh mistress and isn't just your run of the mill citybuilder.

There is a constant need to keep an eye on your town since the overall success of it all boils down to people.  Citizens can die from anything, from workplace accidents to old age.  The loss of just one person can set off a ripple effect that can wreak havoc on your village if you're not careful.

The graphics and sound design are pretty decent, seeing as this game came from what amounts to a one man studio.  Controls are simple and easy to use, and the guts of the simulation will keep you on your toes.

Probably one of the best citybuilding sims I have ever played.  10/10

reviewText:
Banished is a survivalist city builder loosely set to medieval times. You're tasked with keeping your few followers fed, clothed and homed, gathering resources to expand and battling the elements and the terrain. This is much harder than it sounds like, as disasters in the form of disease or fire can hit without warning, nevermind more common occurrences like starvation or hypothermia caused by your mismanagement. All in all, an enjoyable game once you figure out how to grow and diversify your settlement a bit.

The biggest issue I have with the game is how housing distribution is handled, and how little control you have over it. Your citizens will not have children unless they have homes of their own (i.e. adult children do not reproduce). This means that you will either have to constantly build more homes, or suffer devastating generation crashes every so often as widowed old people greedily demand a full household until they die, meaning you'll have fewer families and ultimately even more people above child-rearing age. A demographic disaster can be harder to recover from than anything else the game throws at you, save perhaps a wildfire scorching half your town. If you have a town hall and the ability to bring in nomad settlers, it'll be easier, but often the first pop crash happens long before you get that far.

Given that this is a survivalist game, though, overcoming such challenges is a large part of the game experience. The game does grow on you after a while, and the soothing, perpetual music urges you to continue for that little while more even when bedtime beckons.

Banished is quite decent value for your money, all things considered - just expect some frustration as you learn how to cope with the many hurdles it can toss at you.

reviewText:
3/5 Stars

Pros: This is an open sand box game where you have a lot of freedom to make choices over how your settlers move forward. It is reminiscent of a wilderness version of the old (fill in the blank) Tycoon! games. If you liked those games, I would definitely recommend this game mostly because there aren't a lot of newer games in it's niche. I would recommend starting without natural disasters because at first struggling to move forward is hard enough (and slow enough) in this game without half your village burning to the ground. It's definitely fun once you learn the controls, but it wears off. The graphics seem good for a casual game, and the soundtrack sets a very immersive mood. The controls aren't that difficult to pick up on, and abundant descriptions help you learn as you go. Also the randomly generated geography is both entertaining and beautiful.

Cons:
There's a limit to how long you can play before you get annoyed/bored out of your skull. Commands take annoyingly long to complete. And when you have limited resources (Basically the entire time you play) you're basically watching people die while you wait a painfully long time for workers to collect/make a resource so that you can do something so that they won't die. Even in full fast-forward the game seems to take forever. It probably is a more realistic expectation, it just means that you spend the whole game scrolling around looking for something to do while you anxiously wait for something to finally finish.

Some of the game mechanics are annoying. The merchant ships never have anything that you want, and the few things that you would want (different livestock for example) never arrive. You're supposed to be able to help prevent natural disasters with different structures in the game, but they don't seem to help much (wells don't seem to do much against fires, the sick people wander around outside the hospital and get everybody sick) And it feels like nobody is ever productive. Most annoying of all, Resouce production is stupid slow.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that you buy in the sale because it looks cool and then realise you'll probably never play it. That's exactly what I thought of this game originally. Then, an update appeared on Steam. No idea what the update was but it reminded me of the game and thought I'd try it. 10 hours later and 4 maps later I finally managed to get to a self sustaining village of around 70 citizens.

The game is a challenge, resources are constantly under pressure particularly in the early stage and this is a micro managers dream. You need to shift your dozen or so citizens between various lines of production to stop the village from starving, freezing or without resources. There are a few mods available that make resource production a little bit easier, I used the iron and wood boost for a short while to prevent my city from dying out.

I love city building games, my favourite being Cities Skylines and this game is a medieval city builder with some differences in gameplay which make it unique and make me want to recommend to everyone that enjoys any kind of city building game.

10/10 would let guy get crushed by a rock again.

reviewText: I will start off with saying I put in over 160 hours into the game, according to steam. So with that in mind, I love the balance that the game provides. There is survival, there is city building, there is economy, and death. There is not much of a story to the game, so dont come in expecting to be thrown into a story while you build, you wont find that here. This game is a sandbox. Great modding community though. But its still a sandbox. And what keeps you going after you get the hang of the game is achievement hunting. So many failed towns, so many lives lost in the hunt. Let's take a moment of silence for all the abandoned towns that have perished trying to achieve the ultimate achievements. Alright. Thank you. Anyways.. Its a fun little game that if you love hunting them achievements, this game will keep you interested for a while, or if you love playing around with mods, this is also a thing that kept me hooked for the slow hours of the game. Personally, I love the concuction of the balance of the game, and in fact, I'm going to go play it a little bit more now, still hunting that one have a town of 300 people" achievement. Keep running out of food for my people. Anyways
date: even with no multiplayer or Co-op I still reccomend the hell out of this game. Goes great with listening to podcasts! =D"

reviewText:
This game is like building a house of cards. Not too hard to begin, you think you're doing well. Nearly 200 population, full happiness.

Then some un-noticed event occurs, maybe a little low on logs, iron, coal. Maybe running low on labour causing things to stack up.

Suddenly, you have no tools, work is down to 50% but your population is the same.

But not for much longer, as without tools you run out of logs (so firewood), coal, coats, food, everything. Poeple are dying left and right.

Now you have under 30 populatioon trying to run everything!

Fun, fun game, but trickier than it looks!

reviewText: Let me begin by stating that Banished is not for the faint, It is not a Sim City, It is Not Anno, there is no glorious Empire to be built, no shining Utopian city to be founded, only a handful of citizen, trying to make subsistance living. Banished is a hard game, even on the easiest settings, ensuring the growth of your town is difficult, there will be hard times, starvation, cold, and disease, and that in part is the beauty of this game. This is a true survival game, you must build your town from scratch, what it looks like, and how it functions is heavily determined by your surroundings. Will you develope a large fishing and trade empire,focused around the sole trade river which is the life blood of your town? Will you develope an industrial powerhouse, using mines and Quarries to produce precious stone and iron for tools to then sell for just enough food to ensure most of your citizens make it through the winter? Or will you play a subsistance society, living off the land, replanting trees and harvesting berries from the surrounding woodland, knowing that to grow will take many, many more years? The best part is that the choice is up to you, and this game will kick your ♥♥♥, many many times, before you even have a glimpse of mastery, and a glimpse of a great society. All in all, BUY THIS GAME!

reviewText: I lost so many cities to horrible things, I can't even count.  This game hates you and your puny peasants so it always finds a way to kill you, even when you least expect it.  This one time I had 150 people and 60,000 food units stored, which seemed pretty good to me at the time. I decided to expand my foodonopoly by buying more different seeds and adding more crop fields. I split my chickens/cows/sheep to have my livestock increase. I had to keep building new barns to support my richness. I had 4 mines and 3 quarries, all working at full capacity. I FLOURISHED AND I WAS THE QUEEN AND EVERYTHING WAS JOLLY AS ♥♥♥♥.\nSOMEHOW the food storage plummeted down after I added more crop fields and farms. (which, uh, is supposed to do the opposite) My precious 60,000 sipped through my fingers into oblivion, despite population being pretty much the same. Despite having mor than enough people per crop field, they never managed to harvest things before late autumn (aka when everything DIES before you collect it) even though they always planted everything timely. I have no idea what happened. I am devastated and weeping.\nYet, I always feel the urge to go back and play Banished. Maybe Im masochistic. Maybe it's one of the best city builders out there. Maybe it's Maybelline. 10/10 would die again.

reviewText:
A Briliant City Builder:
The game has a simle concept, you start with a few people, some food, and other supplies, and maybe a few buildings. Now survive. The game Is mirror polished, and executes it's concept beautifully. Everything from the UI to the graphics, to  the sound is great, which is impressice, considering this was all made by one guy (except the music)

In short, if you've been lookign for a new city builder, or like me none of the existing city builders were quite what you were lookign for, i reccomend you give this one a shot.

reviewText: This game is brutal. It doesn't care about you, your time, your buildings, or your villagers. I can't stop playing it. There is no supernatural enemy to fend off, no enemy hordes to fight, it's just your little ragtag group of people versus the elements. And, nine times out of ten, the elements win. Either via starvation or the little idiots freezing to death. You will either play this game for hours on end, or throw your computer across the room in frustration after ten minutes. If you can bend it to your will, you'll enjoy it. If you can't, you'll hate it. Good luck.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the best Indie games on Steam. It's rock solid stable, I've never seen a glitch or so much as a hiccup in my time playing it. It also has one of the best tutorial systems I've ever seen in an Indie game, you can actually learn the game as opposed to going online to watch someone else teach it.

What will keep you coming back is the endless variety. Your maps are based on seeds (a la Minecraft) so each time you play it will be something different and there's a great online community for sharing map seeds.

You won't be disappointed with this game.

reviewText: This game is great. Overall  7.5/10\n\nBought it think it was just gonna be like another sim city or something it was real easy to build a balanced city with a large population. oh boy was i wrong. within the first 2 hours my first town had died, and by the end of the night i had probably restarted about 10 times at just the pure hardness to build a stable town. Due to this frustration it hooks you, you want to proove the game wrong and succeed, and my word be prepared to put in. The graphics of this game does it job, in being detailed enough but not over detailed that your system struggles to run it. Game runs pretty much hassle free from start. If you're into building ctites but without the conflict this is for you, it will provide you with hours of challenges, it the achievements provides you with outcomes to meet to keep the game interesting for you.

reviewText: Roughly two hours into the game, and.. I love it. The game really is well polished. Controls feel great, there's little to wish for in the UI. And the game is hard. I've had a few towns fail fairly quickly, and there's a bunch more to go! I haven't managed to build any of the later stuff, such as education or farming, but that will come! A good purchase, well worth the money.

reviewText: Banished, a City Managment Game we have all dreamed of. No Pescy barbarians at the gates, no zombies trying to eat your townsfolks. Nope none of that, just good ol'City Building. Honestly though, although the game is quite Awesome, Intellegent, and Simple, it still gives anyone a challenge no matter who you are. Whether that challenge be Starvation, Tornados, Lack of Logs, Old Age, or Children. There is always an Adventure waiting for you in the Game of Banished. You just need imagination. XD

reviewText: Waiting for trade boats the game" Is a resource management game to the extreme. While having similar aspects to games in the city building genre such as sim city or tropico it has a slightly different flavor the game is more focused producing the correct amount of resources and managing expansion instead of the normal produce as much resource as humanly possible. I still feel like this game is missing something
date: but even so its fun and relaxing to play.\n\nSpecific complaints there is no way to prioritize stock piles and/or set them to only hold certain resources which can be a giant hassle if you are trying to stream line a wood cutter. Laborers priority settings are lacking if they are out harvesting resources and you drop a house which has a tree on it they will not stop harvesting to remove the tree. While this may just be a complaint I have its a bit tedious to deselect everything drop the house then reselect everything again."

reviewText: One of the best town sims I've ever played. It takes elements from other games like  the Anno series and Knights and Merchants" then rolls them all into one game minus the combat aspect. you start out slumming it struggling to get food and firewood for winter then work your way up to a massive town with over a 100 people. Good micromanagement is a must for this game. The graphics are also quite pretty. Getting to watch the seasons change and seeing how snows and ice affect the villagers in real time can be pretty immersive. I'm already very addicted."

reviewText: This game is the old genre of city building games revived.  If you were a fan of the early settlers, Anno, or Age of Empire Games, then this is for you!  Made by one person, yet still so much better than the supposed AAA games of the genre with 400 people working on it!\nIf your thinking about buying this; stop thinking and do so!  If you think there is even a chance you might enjoy this, there is a 99% chance you will!
